summary: This document is a compilation of court filings from the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330). It primarily concerns disputes over Maxwell's conditions of confinement at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) in Brooklyn, specifically regarding her access to legal discovery materials and the conditions of her detention. The filings include letters from the prosecution, defense, and MDC legal counsel, as well as court orders from Judge Alison J. Nathan.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the criminal case, currently detained at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC) in Brooklyn. The filings focus on her conditions of confinement and access to legal discovery materials.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The presiding judge in the case, issuing orders and rulings on motions related to Maxwell's detention conditions and access to discovery.

persons.name: Heriberto Tellez
persons.role: Warden of the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC)
persons.context: The warden of the MDC Brooklyn. The defense requested he appear before the court to address Maxwell's specialized detention conditions, but the court denied the request.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The lead prosecutor for the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, submitting letters on behalf of the government regarding Maxwell's detention conditions.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP representing Ghislaine Maxwell. He submitted a letter requesting the court order the BOP to give Maxwell weekend/holiday access to a discovery laptop.

connections.description: Maxwell is detained at the MDC under Warden Tellez's authority. The defense alleges Tellez makes decisions about her specialized detention conditions.
Everdell is defense counsel for Maxwell, advocating for improved conditions and access to legal materials on her behalf.
Strauss, as Acting U.S. Attorney, is prosecuting the criminal case against Maxwell.
Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal case and ruling on matters related to her pre-trial detention.

events.title: Defendant's Request Regarding Detention Conditions
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell, through her counsel, submitted a request to the court regarding her conditions of confinement at the MDC, leading to a series of legal exchanges.

events.title: Court Order for MDC Response
events.description: Judge Nathan issued an order concerning Maxwell's confinement, prompting a response from MDC legal counsel.

events.title: MDC Legal Counsel's Response Letter
events.description: MDC legal counsel submitted a letter to Judge Nathan detailing Maxwell's conditions of confinement and asserting they comply with BOP policies.

events.title: Court Denies Request for Warden's Appearance
events.description: Judge Nathan denied Maxwell's request to summon Warden Heriberto Tellez to personally appear and answer questions about her detention conditions.

events.title: Court Orders Weekend Laptop Access
events.description: Judge Nathan granted Maxwell's request, ordering the BOP to give her access to a government-provided discovery laptop on weekends and holidays.

events.title: Court Denies BOP Request to Vacate Laptop Order
events.description: Judge Nathan denied the BOP's request to vacate the January 15 order granting Maxwell weekend/holiday laptop access.

locations: Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC), 80 29th Street, Brooklyn, New York 11232
United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
The Silvio J. Mollo Building, One Saint Andrew's Plaza, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell was held under specialized detention conditions at the MDC Brooklyn, including 24/7 surveillance, frequent searches, and a dedicated three-guard security detail.
The defense argued Maxwell's conditions were overly restrictive and 'specifically target[ed] her,' but the MDC and BOP maintained they were for safety and complied with standard policies.
A significant point of contention was Maxwell's access to a government-provided laptop for reviewing discovery; the court ultimately ordered the BOP to grant her access on weekends and holidays.
The court denied the defense's request to have Warden Heriberto Tellez appear personally, instead relying on written submissions from MDC legal counsel.
The government stated Maxwell had 'more time to review her discovery than any other inmate at the MDC' and more attorney communication time than other inmates.
